The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act requires employers of H-1B nonimmigrants to offer wages at the prevailing wage level or median average wage for the occupational classification in the area of employment. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act mandates that employers of H-1B nonimmigrants must offer wages at the prevailing wage level or median average wage for the occupational classification in the area of employment. The wage determination methodology used must be submitted with the application. Additionally, employers must provide W-2 forms if they have employed H-1B nonimmigrants in a specified previous period. The Secretary requires employers of H-1B nonimmigrants to submit the Internal Revenue Service Form W-2 Wage and Tax Statement for the specified period. SEC. 2. GOOD FAITH RECRUITMENT REQUIREMENT. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding the extension of the time period for no displacement, the requirement for active recruitment, and the prohibition of outplacement for H-1B nonimmigrants. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act prohibits the displacement of H-1B nonimmigrants by another employer. SEC. 3. LABOR ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary will handle investigations of wage complaints and fraud in H-1B visa applications. Additionally, the Secretary may conduct compliance surveys and annual audits for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants. The Secretary will conduct annual compliance audits for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants representing 15 percent or more of their total workforce. SEC. 4 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to make the H-1B nonimmigrant petitioner fee permanent. The effective date for this amendment is petitions filed on or after January 1 of the year following the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 allows individuals harmed by an employer's violation of H-1B requirements to bring a civil action for damages or relief.
